questions.stem: A career counselor administers the Strong Interest Inventory (SII) to a 28-year-old client considering a career change. The client's Occupational Scale for 'Psychologist' yields a score of 58 (Similar). Which of the following BEST describes how this score was derived?

options.text: The client's responses were compared to the theoretical RIASEC profile expected for psychologists using Holland's hexagonal model
The client's item responses were statistically compared to those of a general reference sample and found to differ in the same direction as satisfied psychologists
The client endorsed a high percentage of items on the Investigative and Social General Occupational Themes, which are the dominant themes for psychologists
The client's self-rated competencies and activity preferences were matched against the O*NET occupational requirements for psychologists

questions.explanation: The SII Occupational Scales were developed using the criterion-keying (empirical) method, in which item responses of individuals employed in specific occupations were compared to those of a general reference sample. A 'Similar' score indicates the examinee's response pattern is similar to that of satisfied workers in that occupation. This is the same construction method used for the MMPI clinical scales. The GOTs (not Occupational Scales) map to RIASEC themes, and the SDS (not the SII) emphasizes self-rated competencies.

questions.stem: According to Holland's theory, a client whose three-letter code is RIA would be described as having GREATER consistency than a client whose code is which of the following?

options.text: RIC
RIA
RSE
IRE

questions.explanation: In Holland's theory, consistency refers to the degree to which an individual's top two types are adjacent on the hexagonal model (R-I-A-S-E-C). In the code RIA, the first two types (R and I) are adjacent on the hexagon, indicating high consistency. For RSE, R and S are opposite types on the hexagon (maximally dissimilar), indicating low consistency. RIC has adjacent first two types (R-I), IRE has adjacent first two types (I-R), and RIA itself is the reference. RSE is the only code where the first two types are opposite, making it the least consistent.

questions.stem: In Dawis and Lofquist's Theory of Work Adjustment (TWA), a worker who tolerates a poor match between their values and their job's reinforcers for an extended period before eventually leaving demonstrates which adjustment mode?

options.text: Flexibility
Activeness
Reactiveness
Perseverance

questions.explanation: TWA identifies four adjustment modes when correspondence between the worker and the environment is low. Perseverance refers to the length of time an individual tolerates discorrespondence before leaving the job. Flexibility is the tolerance for discorrespondence itself (how much mismatch the person can endure). Activeness involves attempting to change the work environment to better fit one's needs. Reactiveness involves changing oneself to better fit the work environment.

questions.stem: Gottfredson's theory of circumscription and compromise predicts that when individuals are forced to make career compromises, they will sacrifice career considerations in which order?

options.text: Gender type first, then prestige level, then personal interests
Personal interests first, then gender type, then prestige level
Prestige level first, then personal interests, then gender type
Personal interests first, then prestige level, then gender type

questions.explanation: According to Gottfredson's theory, when forced to compromise career aspirations, individuals sacrifice personal interests first (most easily given up), then prestige level, and protect gender type last (most resistant to compromise). This reflects the developmental sequence in reverse: gender-type boundaries are established earliest (ages 6-8) and are therefore most deeply embedded in the self-concept.

questions.stem: A career counselor uses the Campbell Interest and Skill Survey (CISS) with a client who shows high interest but low self-reported skill in the Creating orientation. According to the CISS interpretive framework, this pattern suggests the client should:

options.text: Pursue careers in this area immediately, as interest is the stronger predictor of satisfaction
Avoid careers in this area, as the skill deficit will lead to frustration
Develop skills in this area through education or training before pursuing related careers
Explore this area further to determine whether the low skill rating reflects genuine limitations or self-underestimation

questions.explanation: The CISS uniquely measures both interests and self-reported skills, creating four interpretive quadrants: Pursue (high interest/high skill), Develop (high interest/low skill), Explore (low interest/high skill), and Avoid (low interest/low skill). High interest with low skill falls in the 'Develop' quadrant, suggesting the client should invest in skill development through education or training. 'Explore' applies to low interest/high skill, not this pattern.

questions.stem: Select ALL factors that Krumboltz's Social Learning Theory of Career Decision Making identifies as influences on career choice.

options.text: Genetic endowment and special abilities
Environmental conditions and events
Congruence between personality type and work environment
Learning experiences (instrumental and associative)
Task approach skills (problem-solving, cognitive responses, work habits)

questions.explanation: Krumboltz identified four factors influencing career decisions: (1) genetic endowment and special abilities, (2) environmental conditions and events, (3) learning experiences (both instrumental -- direct experience with consequences, and associative -- classical conditioning or observation), and (4) task approach skills. Congruence between personality type and work environment is a central concept in Holland's theory, not Krumboltz's social learning approach.

questions.stem: Select ALL characteristics that distinguish the Kuder Career Search from the Strong Interest Inventory.

options.text: Uses forced-choice triads requiring selection of most and least preferred activities
Produces ipsative scores that compare the individual's own interests to each other
Includes a Person Match system comparing profiles to satisfied workers
Uses criterion keying to develop its occupational scales
Is organized around Holland's six RIASEC themes at all scale levels

questions.explanation: The Kuder Career Search is distinguished by: (1) forced-choice triads where examinees pick the most and least preferred activity from sets of three, (2) ipsative scoring that compares an individual's interests relative to their other interests rather than to a normative group, and (3) a Person Match system. Criterion keying is characteristic of the SII's Occupational Scales, not the Kuder. While the Kuder's Activity Preference Scales align with RIASEC themes, this is also true of the SII, so it is not a distinguishing feature.

questions.stem: Select ALL components of Super's Life-Span, Life-Space theory of career development.

options.text: Career choice is an implementation of one's self-concept
The Career Rainbow illustrates multiple life roles enacted simultaneously across different theaters
Career maturity reflects readiness to make age-appropriate career decisions
Self-efficacy beliefs are the most powerful predictor of career choice
Recycling through developmental stages during career transitions is normative, not pathological

questions.explanation: Super's theory includes: self-concept as the keystone of career development, the Career Rainbow model showing multiple simultaneous life roles across life-space and life-span, career maturity as readiness for age-appropriate career decisions, and the mini-cycle concept of normative recycling through stages. Self-efficacy as the most powerful predictor of career choice is a central tenet of SCCT (Lent, Brown, and Hackett), not Super's theory.

questions.stem: A psychologist conducting a comprehensive career assessment battery should include measures of which of the following? Select ALL that apply.

options.text: Vocational interests to identify what activities the client finds appealing
Aptitudes and abilities to identify what the client can do well
Work values to identify what the client finds meaningful and rewarding
Personality type to predict occupational prestige level
Clinical interview exploring career history, work experiences, and barriers

questions.explanation: A thorough career assessment battery integrates: (1) interest inventories (e.g., SII) to identify appealing activities, (2) aptitude/ability measures (e.g., DAT, ASVAB) to identify strengths, (3) values assessments (e.g., MIQ, Work Values Inventory) to identify what is meaningful, and (4) a clinical interview exploring career history and circumstances. Personality assessment can supplement career assessment, but personality type does not predict occupational prestige level -- that reflects individual aspirations and opportunities, not personality traits.

questions.stem: According to Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT), which of the following are identified as key cognitive-person variables that influence career development? Select ALL that apply.

options.text: Self-efficacy beliefs
Outcome expectations
Personal goals
Career maturity
Vocational identity clarity

questions.explanation: SCCT (Lent, Brown, and Hackett, 1994) identifies three key cognitive-person variables: self-efficacy beliefs (confidence in performing specific tasks), outcome expectations (beliefs about consequences of behaviors), and personal goals (intentions to engage in activities or produce outcomes). Career maturity is a concept from Super's theory, and vocational identity clarity is associated with Holland's construct of identity. SCCT proposes that self-efficacy and outcome expectations jointly influence interest development, which shapes goals and actions.

questions.stem: Match each career assessment instrument with its PRIMARY distinguishing characteristic.

columns.text: Measures both interests AND self-reported skills
Uses criterion keying for Occupational Scales
Uses forced-choice triads producing ipsative scores

questions.explanation: The SII's Occupational Scales use criterion keying (comparing examinees' responses to those of satisfied workers vs. a general reference sample). The SDS is uniquely self-administered, self-scored, and self-interpreted, requiring no professional involvement. The Kuder uses forced-choice triads producing ipsative (within-person) scores. The CISS uniquely measures both interests and self-reported skills on parallel scales, generating the Pursue/Develop/Explore/Avoid quadrants.

questions.stem: Match each career development theory with its KEY concept or contribution.

columns.text: Planned happenstance and openness to unplanned career opportunities
Correspondence between worker needs/values and job reinforcers predicts satisfaction
Career choice implements self-concept across developmental stages
Person-environment congruence across six personality/environment types

questions.explanation: Holland's theory centers on congruence between six personality types and six work environment types (RIASEC). Super's theory emphasizes career development as implementation of the self-concept across life stages. Krumboltz applied social learning to career development and later introduced planned happenstance. TWA focuses on the correspondence between an individual's needs/values and the job's reinforcers (satisfaction) and between abilities and job requirements (satisfactoriness).

questions.stem: For each Holland RIASEC type, select ALL occupations that are typically associated with that type. Some occupations may appear to fit multiple types, but select the PRIMARY classification.
questions.explanation: In Holland's RIASEC model: Realistic types prefer hands-on, mechanical work (electrician). Investigative types prefer analytical, scientific activities (research scientist). Social types prefer helping, teaching, and counseling activities (school counselor). Enterprising types prefer persuading, leading, and selling (sales manager). Each occupation is primarily classified under one type, although most real occupations have multi-letter Holland codes.

questions.stem: For each career development theorist, select ALL concepts that are DIRECTLY associated with their theory.
questions.explanation: Super developed the Career Rainbow model showing multiple life roles across the life-space. Gottfredson proposed that circumscription progressively narrows the 'zone of acceptable alternatives.' Savickas extended Super's work with the concept of career adaptability comprising four Cs: Concern, Control, Curiosity, and Confidence. Roe proposed that early parent-child relationships (overprotective, avoidant, accepting) influence career orientation toward person-oriented vs. non-person-oriented occupations.

questions.stem: In Holland's hexagonal model, adjacent types such as Realistic and Investigative are expected to show {{blank1}} correlations, while opposite types such as Realistic and Social are expected to show {{blank2}} correlations. A person whose top two Holland types are adjacent demonstrates high {{blank3}}, while a person whose profile shows clear peaks and valleys rather than flat elevations demonstrates high {{blank4}}.

options.text: moderate to strong positive
near zero or negative
uniformly high positive
low to moderate negative
moderate to strong positive
near zero or negative
uniformly high positive
moderate positive
congruence
differentiation
consistency
identity
congruence
differentiation
consistency
calculus

questions.explanation: Holland's calculus assumption predicts that adjacent types on the hexagon show moderate to strong positive correlations, while opposite types show near zero or negative correlations. Consistency refers to having adjacent types as one's top two codes (e.g., RI or SE). Differentiation refers to the clarity of the profile -- clear peaks and valleys indicate strong differentiation, while a flat profile indicates undifferentiation. Congruence refers to the person-environment match, not the profile shape.

questions.stem: In the Theory of Work Adjustment (TWA), {{blank1}} refers to the worker's subjective contentment when the job provides reinforcers that meet the worker's needs, while {{blank2}} refers to the employer's evaluation that the worker's abilities meet the performance requirements. The primary assessment instrument associated with TWA is the {{blank3}}, which measures 20 psychological needs organized into six work values. When correspondence between person and environment is low, the worker may attempt to change the work environment, which TWA calls {{blank4}}.

options.text: satisfaction
satisfactoriness
tenure
correspondence
satisfaction
satisfactoriness
tenure
flexibility
Work Values Inventory
Career Maturity Inventory
Minnesota Importance Questionnaire (MIQ)
Values Scale
reactiveness
flexibility
perseverance
activeness

questions.explanation: TWA distinguishes between satisfaction (worker's contentment when needs/values are met by job reinforcers) and satisfactoriness (employer's assessment that the worker's abilities meet job requirements). The MIQ measures 20 psychological needs across six values (Achievement, Comfort, Status, Altruism, Safety, Autonomy) and is the primary instrument for TWA. Activeness involves changing the work environment, while reactiveness involves changing oneself. Flexibility is tolerance for mismatch, and perseverance is the duration of tolerance before leaving.

questions.stem: A 17-year-old high school student presents for career counseling with an undifferentiated RIASEC profile on the Self-Directed Search (all six scores within 3 points of each other) and reports feeling completely lost about future career plans. The student expresses equal disinterest in most school subjects and has limited extracurricular involvement.

options.text: Limited exposure to diverse activities and occupational options
Normal developmental stage with insufficient career exploration experiences
Clinical depression requiring immediate psychiatric referral
Invalid SDS administration due to random responding
Low vocational identity and career immaturity reflected in an undifferentiated interest profile
Personality disorder with identity diffusion manifesting in vocational indecision
Aptitude deficiency across all domains preventing career interest crystallization
Broaden experiential exposure through internships, volunteer work, and informational interviews
Use career counseling to explore personal values, strengths, and life themes
Administer an IQ test to identify aptitude areas that could guide career selection
Recommend the student choose a career immediately to reduce anxiety

questions.explanation: An undifferentiated RIASEC profile in a 17-year-old most likely reflects limited exposure to diverse activities and developmental career immaturity, which is normal for the Exploration stage (Super) at this age. The central issue is low vocational identity and career immaturity. Appropriate interventions include broadening experiential exposure and career counseling focused on values and strengths. Interest inventories measure enjoyment preferences, not abilities, so an IQ test would not address the interest differentiation problem. Pressuring immediate career choice is contraindicated.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old client who has worked as an accountant for 10 years reports growing dissatisfaction with work. The Minnesota Importance Questionnaire reveals high needs for Creativity and Autonomy, but the client's current Occupational Reinforcer Pattern shows the accounting environment provides primarily Safety and Conventional reinforcers. The Strong Interest Inventory yields a code of AIE (Artistic, Investigative, Enterprising).

options.text: Discorrespondence between worker values (Creativity, Autonomy) and job reinforcers (Safety, Conventional)
SII code (AIE) is incongruent with current Conventional work environment
The MIQ results are invalid because they conflict with 10 years of job tenure
The client lacks the cognitive ability for more creative careers
Poor person-environment fit resulting in low satisfaction despite adequate satisfactoriness
Midlife crisis unrelated to vocational factors requiring psychotherapy rather than career counseling
Burnout syndrome requiring stress management intervention before career exploration
Explore occupations congruent with AIE code that satisfy Creativity and Autonomy values
Use Savickas's Career Construction Interview to identify life themes and career narratives
Recommend returning to school for a degree in fine arts as the only path forward
Administer the MMPI-2 to assess for underlying psychopathology causing the dissatisfaction

questions.explanation: This case illustrates TWA concepts: there is discorrespondence between the client's values and the job's reinforcers, resulting in low satisfaction despite adequate ability (satisfactoriness). The SII code confirms incongruence with the current environment. The core problem is poor person-environment fit. Appropriate recommendations include exploring congruent occupations and using career construction approaches. The MIQ results are not invalid simply because the client has stayed in the job -- perseverance (tolerance for discorrespondence) varies. Prescribing a specific career path or assuming psychopathology is inappropriate.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding the Strong Interest Inventory (SII).
questions.passage: The Strong Interest Inventory is a widely used vocational assessment tool. [The SII Occupational Scales were developed using criterion keying, comparing the responses of satisfied workers in specific occupations to those of a general reference sample]. [The SII produces ipsative scores that cannot be compared across individuals because they use forced-choice triads]. [The General Occupational Themes (GOTs) map directly to Holland's six RIASEC types]. [The SII measures what activities a person will be good at, not just what they find appealing]. [The Personal Style Scales assess preferences for work style, learning environment, leadership style, risk taking, and team orientation]. [The Basic Interest Scales use criterion keying to identify specific interest clusters within each General Occupational Theme].

highlightableSegments.text: The SII Occupational Scales were developed using criterion keying, comparing the responses of satisfied workers in specific occupations to those of a general reference sample
The SII produces ipsative scores that cannot be compared across individuals because they use forced-choice triads
The General Occupational Themes (GOTs) map directly to Holland's six RIASEC types
The SII measures what activities a person will be good at, not just what they find appealing
The Personal Style Scales assess preferences for work style, learning environment, leadership style, risk taking, and team orientation
The Basic Interest Scales use criterion keying to identify specific interest clusters within each General Occupational Theme

questions.explanation: Correct statements: (1) The SII Occupational Scales use criterion keying. (2) The GOTs map to RIASEC types. (3) The PSS assesses five preference dimensions. Incorrect statements: The SII uses normative scoring, not ipsative -- it is the Kuder that uses forced-choice triads and ipsative scores. Interest inventories measure what a person finds appealing, NOT what they will be good at (interests and aptitudes are independent). The Basic Interest Scales use homogeneous item clustering (items that intercorrelate), not criterion keying -- only the Occupational Scales use criterion keying.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe Gottfredson's theory of circumscription and compromise.
questions.passage: Gottfredson's theory addresses the developmental process of career aspiration formation. [During Stage 2 (ages 6-8), children eliminate occupations perceived as gender-inappropriate, establishing sex-type boundaries]. [When forced to compromise, individuals sacrifice gender type first because it was established earliest in development]. [Stage 3 (ages 9-13) involves orientation to social valuation where children eliminate occupations perceived as too low or too high in prestige]. [The circumscription process progressively narrows the zone of acceptable alternatives through stages oriented to size and power, sex roles, social valuation, and unique self]. [Circumscription is easily reversed through career counseling interventions that reopen previously eliminated alternatives]. [Stage 4 (age 14+) involves orientation to the internal, unique self where individuals refine choices based on personal interests, values, and abilities].

highlightableSegments.text: During Stage 2 (ages 6-8), children eliminate occupations perceived as gender-inappropriate, establishing sex-type boundaries
When forced to compromise, individuals sacrifice gender type first because it was established earliest in development
Stage 3 (ages 9-13) involves orientation to social valuation where children eliminate occupations perceived as too low or too high in prestige
The circumscription process progressively narrows the zone of acceptable alternatives through stages oriented to size and power, sex roles, social valuation, and unique self
Circumscription is easily reversed through career counseling interventions that reopen previously eliminated alternatives
Stage 4 (age 14+) involves orientation to the internal, unique self where individuals refine choices based on personal interests, values, and abilities

questions.explanation: Accurate statements describe the four stages correctly and the progressive narrowing of the zone of acceptable alternatives. Incorrect: Gender type is the LAST thing sacrificed in compromise (not the first) -- individuals sacrifice interests first, then prestige, and protect gender type last. Also, circumscription is NOT easily reversed; once options are eliminated from the zone of acceptable alternatives, they are difficult to reintroduce, which is a key implication of Gottfredson's theory for career counseling.

questions.stem: Arrange Super's career development stages in their correct chronological order from earliest to latest.

items.text: Exploration (ages 15-24): Crystallizing, specifying, and implementing vocational preferences
Growth (birth-14): Developing self-concept and work orientation through fantasy, interests, and capacities
Disengagement (65+): Decelerating, retirement planning, and retirement living
Maintenance (45-64): Holding, updating, and innovating within established career
Establishment (25-44): Stabilizing, consolidating, and advancing in chosen occupation

questions.explanation: Super's five career development stages proceed in order: Growth (birth-14), Exploration (15-24), Establishment (25-44), Maintenance (45-64), and Disengagement (65+). Each stage has specific developmental tasks. Super also proposed that individuals may recycle through these stages (mini-cycles) during career transitions, and this recycling is considered normative rather than pathological.

questions.stem: According to Gottfredson's theory, arrange the four stages of circumscription in their correct developmental order from earliest to latest.

items.text: Stage 3: Orientation to social valuation -- elimination based on prestige level (ages 9-13)
Stage 1: Orientation to size and power -- recognition that adults hold occupational roles (ages 3-5)
Stage 4: Orientation to internal, unique self -- refinement based on personal interests and values (age 14+)
Stage 2: Orientation to sex roles -- elimination of gender-inappropriate occupations (ages 6-8)

questions.explanation: Gottfredson's four stages of circumscription proceed: Stage 1 (ages 3-5, size and power), Stage 2 (ages 6-8, sex roles), Stage 3 (ages 9-13, social valuation/prestige), Stage 4 (age 14+, internal unique self). Each stage progressively narrows the zone of acceptable alternatives. Notably, compromise operates in reverse order: interests (developed last) are sacrificed first, prestige second, and gender type (established earliest) is protected last.

questions.stem: A longitudinal study follows two groups of individuals from high school through midlife, tracking their vocational interest stability using the Strong Interest Inventory General Occupational Themes. Group A is assessed at ages 18, 25, 35, and 45. Group B members experienced major career transitions (job loss, industry change) at approximately age 30.
questions.question: Which interpretation of these test-retest correlation data is most consistent with the research literature on interest stability?

options.text: Interest stability peaks in adolescence and declines steadily throughout adulthood
Interests are highly stable after age 25, with temporary instability during career transitions representing normative recycling through developmental stages
Career transitions permanently destabilize vocational interests, as shown by Group B never reaching Group A's stability levels
Both groups demonstrate that interest inventories have inadequate test-retest reliability for clinical use

questions.explanation: Research consistently shows that vocational interests are relatively stable over time, particularly after age 25, with test-retest correlations for the Strong GOTs ranging from .80-.92 over 1-5 year periods. Group B's temporary decrease in stability around age 35 (following a career transition at 30) is consistent with Super's concept of mini-cycles, where individuals recycle through developmental stages during transitions. The subsequent recovery to high stability by age 45 shows that transitions temporarily disrupt but do not permanently destabilize interests.

questions.stem: A researcher examines the relationship between Holland congruence scores and two work outcomes across five levels of congruence (from lowest to highest person-environment match).
questions.question: Based on the data pattern, which conclusion about Holland's congruence hypothesis is best supported?

options.text: Congruence is equally predictive of both job satisfaction and job performance
Congruence is a stronger predictor of job satisfaction than of job performance, consistent with the meta-analytic literature
Congruence has no meaningful relationship with either outcome, disconfirming Holland's theory
The relationship between congruence and outcomes is curvilinear, with moderate congruence being optimal

questions.explanation: The data show that job satisfaction increases substantially across congruence levels (from 2.1 to 4.7, a 2.6-point increase), while job performance shows a much smaller increase (from 3.0 to 3.7, only 0.7 points). This pattern is consistent with the meta-analytic research showing that Holland's congruence is a stronger predictor of job satisfaction than of job performance. The relationship is positive and approximately linear for both outcomes, not curvilinear.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept according to the career development theory with which it is PRIMARILY associated.

items.text: Hexagonal model of RIASEC types
Career Rainbow showing multiple life roles
Self-efficacy as strongest predictor of career interests
Congruence, consistency, and differentiation
Archway Model with self-concept as keystone
Performance accomplishments as the most powerful source of career confidence

questions.explanation: Holland's Theory: The hexagonal model and the constructs of congruence, consistency, and differentiation. Super's Theory: The Career Rainbow model (multiple life roles across life-space) and the Archway Model (self-concept as keystone integrating career development factors). SCCT: Self-efficacy as the strongest predictor of career interests and choices, with performance accomplishments identified (following Bandura) as the most powerful source of self-efficacy.

questions.stem: Categorize each scale or feature according to its correct interest inventory.

items.text: Occupational Scales developed via criterion keying
Self-administered, self-scored, self-interpreted format
Forced-choice triads producing ipsative scores
Basic Interest Scales and Personal Style Scales
Activities, Competencies, Occupations, and Self-Estimates sections
Person Match system comparing profiles to satisfied workers

questions.explanation: SII features: Occupational Scales (criterion-keyed), Basic Interest Scales, Personal Style Scales, and General Occupational Themes. SDS features: self-administered/scored/interpreted format with four sections (Activities, Competencies, Occupations, Self-Estimates) yielding a three-letter Summary Code. Kuder features: forced-choice triads producing ipsative scores and the Person Match system for comparing profiles. These distinctions are heavily tested on the EPPP.
